title.native: ノーゲーム・ノーライフ ゼロ

description:
A movie adaptation of the sixth volume of the light novel series announced at the MF Bunko J Summer School Festival 2016 event.

Six thousand years before Sora and Shiro were even a blink in the history of Disboard, war consumed the land, tearing apart the heavens, destroying stars, and even threatening to wipe out the human race. Amid the chaos and destruction, a young man named Riku leads humanity toward the tomorrow his heart believes in. One day, in the ruins of an Elf city, he meets Schwi, a female exiled "Ex Machina" android who asks him to teach her what it means to have a human heart.

(Source: Sentai Filmworks)
synonyms: โนเกม โนไลฟ์ เดอะมูฟวี่
โนเกม โนไลฟ์ ซีโร่

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Espionage
tags.description: Prominently features characters infiltrating an organization in order to steal sensitive information.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Class Struggle
tags.description: Contains conflict born between the different social classes. Generally between an dominant elite and a suffering oppressed group.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Board Game
tags.description: Centers around characters playing board games.

tags.name: Elf
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is an elf.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Survival
tags.description: Centers around the struggle to live in spite of extreme obstacles.

tags.name: Robots
tags.description: Prominently features humanoid machines.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Reincarnation
tags.description: Features a character being born again after death, typically as another person or in another world.

tags.name: Isekai
tags.description: Features characters being transported into an alternate world setting and having to adapt to their new surroundings.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/yuukamiya68) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/user/yuukamiya68)

Born and raised in Brazil, then moved to Japan and became a manga artist. His real name is Thiago Furukawa Lucas. Married his assistant, mangaka and illustrator [Mashiro Hiiragi](https://anilist.co/staff/116029/Mashiro-Hiiragi), in August 2011.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/いしづかあつこ) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atsuko_Ishizuka)

Affiliated with [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/).

Known for directing shows such as [A Place Further Than the Universe](https://anilist.co/anime/99426/), and [No Game No Life](https://anilist.co/anime/19815/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oitan125) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/花田十輝)

Jukki Hanada is a Japanese screenwriter and novelist. He is the grandson of literary critic and essayist Kiyoteru Hanada. He formerly belonged to [Takao Koyama's](https://anilist.co/staff/117575/Takao-Koyama) Brother Noppo anime scenario house. He's currently affiliated with SATZ.

He's a big fan of professional baseball and supports the Hiroshima Toyo Carp.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/明田川仁)

Affiliated with Magic Capsule, a recording studio led by his father [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062).

[Website](http://meganebanchow.com/) | [Blog](http://meganebanchow.jugem.jp/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MeganeBanchow)

Also worked on the music for Denpa Onna to Seishun Otoko as part of the unit Franz Maxwell I.

[Website](http://konomi-suzuki.net/) | [Old Blog](http://ameblo.jp/galapa-konomi) | [New Blog](http://ameblo.jp/konomi-suzuki/)

Konomi Suzuki is a Japanese singer from Osaka Prefecture who is signed to Amuleto. After winning the Animax All-Japan Anisong Grand Prix in 2011, she made her debut in 2012 with the release of her first single "Choir Jail", which peaked at 34 on the Oricon charts; the title track of which was used as the opening theme to the anime television series Dusk Maiden of Amnesia. She released her first album 17, in 2014, two albums in 2015, and a further album Lead, in 2016.

Suzuki cites the character Sheryl Nome from Macross Frontier as her inspiration for making music for anime. Her music has been featured in anime series such as The Pet Girl of Sakurasou, No Matter How I Look at It, It's You Guys' Fault I'm Not Popular!, No Game No Life, and Re:Zero − Starting Life in Another World. She has also performed in events in Japan such as Animelo Summer Live and Animax Musix, and at international events in China, Germany, the United States, and Southeast Asia. In 2018, Suzuki made her voice acting debut, playing the role of Rin in the anime television series Lost Song.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/いしづかあつこ) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atsuko_Ishizuka)

Affiliated with [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/).

Known for directing shows such as [A Place Further Than the Universe](https://anilist.co/anime/99426/), and [No Game No Life](https://anilist.co/anime/19815/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oitan125) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/花田十輝)

Jukki Hanada is a Japanese screenwriter and novelist. He is the grandson of literary critic and essayist Kiyoteru Hanada. He formerly belonged to [Takao Koyama's](https://anilist.co/staff/117575/Takao-Koyama) Brother Noppo anime scenario house. He's currently affiliated with SATZ.

He's a big fan of professional baseball and supports the Hiroshima Toyo Carp.

Asaka joined [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) after graduating from Osaka Designers' College. There his first job was working as an assistant director for [Toshio Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/117533/) on [Phoenix: Yamato Chapter](https://anilist.co/anime/2999/). Later he made his debut as an episode director on [Yawara!](https://anilist.co/anime/691/), and soon after as a director on [Pops](https://anilist.co/anime/2093). His notable works include [Cardcaptor Sakura](https://anilist.co/anime/232/), [Nana](https://anilist.co/anime/877/), [Chihayafuru](https://anilist.co/anime/10800/), and [My Love Story!!](https://anilist.co/anime/20946/) among others.

Many of his works take on a female perspective for the telling of the story, with a feminine protagonist as the central focus. This has contributed to him becoming the main director at Madhouse for handling the more serious series featuring female characters or targeting the female market.

Graduated: Aichi University of the Arts (March, 2007)

Kotono Watanabe is a Japanese director and storyboard artist, who mainly does episode direction. After her graduation from Aichi University she joined studio Madhouse in April of the same year.

Freelancer. Recognizable for his bassy and often reverbed sound effects.

Regularly works with [Yoshikazu Iwanami](https://anilist.co/staff/101016/) and [Jin Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/103074/).
Kimura Kashiko is an editor working for Mad Box.
